info.game_comments:
2001 College Championship quarterfinal game 3.
From the campus at UCLA.

(1, 1).clue: He concludes Dickens' "A Christmas Carol" by saying, "God bless us, every one"

(2, 1).clue: To compete with the Sony PlayStation 2, Microsoft has the Xbox & this company has the GameCube

(4, 1).clue: This stimulant is considered the most commonly consumed drug in the U.S.

(5, 1).clue: Museum-hopping?  You'll find the Burke Museum of Natural History & Culture on this Seattle school's campus

(6, 1).clue: This 2-letter word is one of only 4 in the English language in which an F is pronounced like a V

(1, 2).clue: The object of Quasimodo's affections, she was later executed for witchcraft

(2, 2).clue: The game for this 2001 Disney under-the-sea animated feature has a multiplayer online mode

(4, 2).clue: Because it acts as a bronchodilator, theophylline is used to treat emphysema, bronchitis & this chronic disease

(5, 2).clue: In 1997 Jodie Foster received an honorary doctorate from this Connecticut university, her alma mater

(6, 2).clue: Meaning "having imagined while asleep", it's one of the few English words that end with "MT"

(1, 3).clue: This old charismatic vampire initiates Louis in "Interview with the Vampire"

(2, 3).clue: "Exile", seen here, is the third installment in this top-selling series

(4, 3).clue: In the mid-1990s the diet drug with this homophonic name dangerously paired an appetite suppressant & a stimulant

(5, 3).clue: This Nashville school named for a commodore is famed for its Intelligent Robotics Lab

(6, 3).clue: This day of the week is the only day with an anagram that's a real English word (it's "dynamo")

(1, 4).clue: It's the nickname of John Updike's Harry Angstrom

(2, 4).clue: You like action?  Hunt for this author's Red Storm games like "Rainbow Six" & "Ghost Recon"

(4, 4).clue: Often used as rodent poison, this alkaloid has been used medicinally as a tonic & a stimulant

(5, 4).clue: If you're walking around this Durham, North Carolina university, watch out for gargoyles like the one seen here

(6, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew pans for gold along the banks of the river at Marshall Gold Discovery Park.)  From the Latin for "outlook", he's often depicted as a grizzled man who searches for gold

(1, 5).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew reports from Central Park.)  From up here on Alice's mushroom, I can read lines from this poem that begins, "Twas brillig, and the slithy toves..."

(2, 5).clue: Dr. Aki Ross, seen here, is from the 2001 film inspired by this game series

(4, 5).clue: Also called adrenaline, this hormone is used to restore heart rhythm in cardiac arrest

(5, 5).clue: To find out more about this East Coast university, check out the online version of its Encyclopedia Brunoniana

(6, 5).clue: The shortest name of a scientific "-ology" is this one that means the study of eggs

(1, 1).clue: The first stone for this Roman basilica was laid in 1506, following the plan of Italian architect Donato Bramante

(2, 1).clue: Like the breathing organs of fish, some fungi have openings called these

(3, 1).clue: Drew a chalk outline near the Roman Senate for this man in 44 B.C.; perps used knives

(4, 1).clue: Of Kix, Trix & Crispix, this cereal maker makes 2

(5, 1).clue: I'm crazy about dancing dinnerware, so "be my guest" at a performance of this Disney musical

(6, 1).clue: A woodwind mouth part & a hoofed, ruminant mammal

(1, 2).clue: The Louvre's sculpture of this Greek goddess of Samothrace is also called "Winged Victory"

(2, 2).clue: This name is used to identify plants that consist of both algae & fungi

(3, 2).clue: A real Greek tragedy: this future king of Thebes offed his old man & shacked up with his mom

(4, 2).clue: Solids & stripes & dots, oh my!  Willie Mosconi only sank 2 of the 3 in this game

(5, 2).clue: Thou shalt not miss "Thou Shalt Not" because it features songs by this singer & pianist seen here

(1, 3).clue: The influence of Cubism on this artist is apparent in the work seen here

(2, 3).clue: Buy them a beer!  These fungi cause the fermentation that produces alcoholic beverages

(3, 3).clue: This advisor to Czar Nicholas II was poisoned, shot & drowned in 1916; guess we can rule out suicide

(4, 3).clue: Of 1001, 2001 & 3001, only 2 were odyssey years for this author's space tales

(5, 3).clue: You might find "Me And Bobby McGee" at "Love, Janis", the Off-Broadway show about this '60s singer

(6, 3).clue: A starchy, tuberous root & the month it can be planted

(1, 4).clue: This painter married Diego Rivera in 1929, divorced him in 1939 & married him again in 1940

(2, 4).clue: Tinea pedis is the technical name for this fungal sports malady

(3, 4).clue: This mobster who developed Vegas was rubbed out in his girlfriend's mansion in 1947; forget it, Jake, it's Beverly Hills

(4, 4).clue: Of Oscar, Tony & Grammy, Yul Brynner picked up 2 of the 3 in the 1950s for his role in this

(5, 4).clue: "Let's Do The Time Warp" at this musical that does not--repeat, does not--have the word "Picture" in its title

(6, 4).clue: To arrange the video & audio of a film & the rise & fall of the ocean

(1, 5).clue: This society painter's "Portrait of Madame X" seen here caused such a scandal that he left Paris for London

(2, 5).clue: Fungi are distinguished from other plants by a lack of this green pigment

(3, 5).clue: Found this revolutionary in a bloody bathtub in 1793 France; had to get a painter to recreate the crime scene

(4, 5).clue: Of furniture, handicrafts & babies, this Quaker offshoot led by Ann Lee makes only 2 of the 3

(5, 5).clue: I could see this long-running musical over & over because I'm nuts about the song "Seasons Of Love"

(6, 5).clue: The Greek god of love & having aches & pains

(0, 0).clue: Of the 4 state capitals named for U.S. presidents, it's the one that's farthest south
